                        IntroductionThe boreal summer intraseasonal oscillation (BSISO) is a key subseasonal variability in the tropics during boreal summer1,2,3,4,5,6. Unlike its wintertime counterpart, the Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO)7,8,9,10, BSISO shows more complex evolutions, with northeastward propagation over the Indo-Pacific basin and eastward propagation along the equator1,2,3,4,5,6. The BSISO convective system not only impacts tropical weather and climate11,12,13,14,15 but also influences extreme events in the subtropics and midlatitudes10,16,17,18,19,20,21,22 through atmospheric teleconnections. For example, quasi-stationary wave trains driven by anomalous BSISO convection over the tropical central-to-eastern Pacific can increase summer heatwaves and wildfire risks in the Pacific Northwest (PNW) region of North America22. The unprecedented PNW heatwave in June 2021, resulting in ~1000 deaths and numerous wildfires, was partly linked to anomalous BSISO convection22,23. Thus, it is imperative to understand and predict how BSISO and its remote impacts will change in a warming climate.How the MJO might change during boreal winter in the future has been extensively investigated8,9,24,25,26,27, but less attention has been given to how BSISO will evolve under a warming climate28,29,30. Generally, a warmer climate is expected to intensify MJO precipitation due to a stronger vertical moisture gradient from SST warming over the tropical Pacific26,27,31,32,33. This, however, does not necessarily apply to the MJO wind variability34,35,36 due to an enhanced top-heavy heating profile and increased static stability24,26,34,35,36,37,38. Similarly, BSISO is expected to intensify in response to increased moisture and moist static energy due to SST warming over the Indo-Pacific basin under a high-emission scenario28,29,30. Besides, a stronger northward BSISO propagation is projected in the future compared to the present day due to a wetter background and more intense ascent at the top of the planetary boundary layer28,30. However, future changes in the zonal extent of BSISO remain unclear, with important implications on the teleconnection and remote climatic impacts of intraseasonal oscillations27,34,39.Based on climate models that reasonably simulate the MJO, Zhou39 showed an eastward-extended teleconnection pattern in boreal winter under a high-emission scenario. This is due to an eastward extension of MJO convection by ~2° in response to enhanced warming east of the climatological warm pool and an eastward shift by ~6° in the subtropical jet exit region, amplifying the impacts of MJO on the Pacific-North America region. Some studies28,29 reported a BSISO eastward propagation of BSISO under a warming climate, but the results were based on a single model realization and might lack generality. Another recent study based on a multi-model ensemble did not find an eastward extension or shift in response to warming30. However, the selected multi-model ensemble used in that study failed to capture the present-day BSISO convection east of 130°E in observations30, which is a key source of the teleconnection wave pattern affecting weather and climate extremes over North America and the North Atlantic16,22,40.More importantly, while the evolution of MJO teleconnections and their impacts in the future has been a subject of intense research27,39,41,42,43,44,45,46, previous studies have largely ignored how the BSISO teleconnection pattern will change and affect risks of extreme weather in downstream regions under anthropogenic warming. Here, using multiple Earth system models that properly simulate the BSISO and its associated large-scale teleconnection pattern, we examine the projected changes in the location of the BSISO convective system and its teleconnection under a warming climate. Given that shifts in the teleconnection wave train can influence regional climate conditions, we further investigate the implications for heatwaves and wildfire risks over North America.ResultsRobust eastward shift of BSISO system under a warming climateWe investigate the response of the BSISO convective system to anthropogenic warming using eleven state-of-the-art climate models from the CMIP6 archives, selected based on their ability to properly simulate the present-day BSISO life cycle and mean-state patterns (see Methods; Supplementary Fig. S1 and Table S1). Our focus is on the boreal summer (June to August), when the BSISO and its teleconnection are most pronounced in the Northern Hemisphere3,16,22 and North America experiences its hot season. Daily anomalous patterns are band-passed (25–90 days) and composited according to the BSISO phases (see Methods) to extract BSISO-induced signals. In the present day (contours in Fig. 1 and Supplementary Fig. S2), BSISO convection, indicated by negative outgoing longwave radiation (OLR) anomalies, mainly occurs in the tropical Indo-Pacific basin (gray box in Fig. 1). The BSISO develops over the tropical central Indian Ocean in phases 8–1 and splits into two parts in phases 2–3 (dashed contours in Supplementary Fig. S2). One part moves eastward toward the Maritime Continent, while the other moves northward or northeastward in the northern Indian Ocean. In phases 4–5, the BSISO forms a northwest-southeast tilted convection band from the South Asian monsoon region to the tropical western North Pacific. In phases 6–7, the convection moves and extends northeastward to the central-to-eastern North Pacific along the intertropical convergence zone. These characteristics of BSISO convection, noted in observations by previous studies3,5,6,22, can be reasonably captured by the selected eleven Earth-system models.Fig. 1: Eastward shift of the boreal summer intraseasonal oscillation (BSISO) system.A, B BSISO phase-longitude Hovmöller diagrams of meridionally-averaged outgoing longwave radiation (OLR) anomalies over (A) 5°S–5°N and (B) 15°N–20°N. Shading denotes the projected changes in OLR anomalies under the high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5), while contours show the present-day composite of OLR anomalies in 1980–2014 in the historical run. The BSISO events are identified using the daily bimodal index (See Methods). C BSISO convective centroid defined by precipitation in observations (cross dot) and the historical (blue dot) and SSP5-8.5 (red dot) experiments (See Methods). Hollow dots represent individual models. Horizontal and vertical lines indicate the range of \(\pm 1\) standard deviation across models. D Projected changes in OLR anomalies in BSISO phases 6 and 7 under the SSP5-8.5 scenario. Contours denote the present-day composite of OLR anomalies in the historical run. Interval levels of present-day OLR anomalies are –10, –6, –2, 2, 6, 10 W m–2. Stippling in (A, B, D) denotes consistent sign of projected changes across >70% of the models. Gray boxes in (A, B, D) refer to the longitude range where BSISO eastward shift occurs as indicated by the red arrows.Full size imageUnder the high-emission scenario, Shared Socio-economic Pathways (SSP) 5–8.5, a robust eastward shift of the BSISO convective system is evident from the concurrent composites of anomalous OLR and precipitation centroid (Fig. 1). Over present-day convection centers, projected changes in OLR anomalies show the opposite signs to those in the present day, indicating that these centers will weaken (Fig. 1A, B and Fig. S2). Meanwhile, projected OLR changes east of present-day centers share the same signs as the present-day centers. Specifically, in phases 6–7, the magnitude of negative OLR anomalies is projected to further increase over the tropical central-to-eastern North Pacific (150°E–150°W; Fig. 1B and D), while it weakens over the main western North Pacific convective center (100°E–150°E).To better quantify the eastward shift, we calculate the centroid of BSISO-related precipitation over the tropical Indo-Pacific basin (Fig. 1C; See Methods). All reported ranges represent the multi-model mean \(\pm\) one standard deviation across models. Under the SSP5-8.5 scenario for 2065–2099, the longitudinal centroid of the BSISO is projected to shift eastward significantly by 2.69° (0.28° to 5.10°), relative to 1980–2014. Statistically significant eastward shifts are found in four BSISO phase pairs (Supplementary Table S2), mainly occurring in BSISO phases 4–5 (2.84° [0.17° to 5.51°]) and 6–7 (2.85° [–0.06° to 5.77°]). Besides changes in OLR and precipitation, anomalous vertical velocity at 500 hPa and zonal wind at 850 hPa also consistently show a robust eastward shift under the future warming climate (Supplementary Fig. S3). Changes in longitudinal centroid based on the real-time multivariate BSISO index (see Methods) further confirm this significant eastward shift (2.63° [0.34° to 4.93°]; Supplementary Fig. S4). Despite the longitudinal shift, shifts in the latitudinal centroid are not significant (–0.12° [–0.42° to 0.19°]; Fig. 1C).Changes in the zonal extent of the BSISO location will alter regional convective activity. A regional space-time power spectra analysis from the tropical Indian Ocean to the Maritime Continent and over the tropical Pacific was conducted to explore potential changes (See Methods). Projected changes in space-time power spectra at intraseasonal timescale over these two regions under the high-emission scenario are shown in Fig. 2. In the 25-to-90-day frequency band, regional space-time power spectra are projected to decrease over the tropical Indian Ocean and increase over the tropical Pacific, indicating weakened and enhanced local BSISO convection, respectively. Similar conclusions can also be found in the zonal wind (Supplementary Fig. S5). The results above indicate a robust eastward shift of the BSISO convection and associated circulation under a warming climate.Fig. 2: Historical and projected regional space-time spectra of intraseasonal OLR over.A Tropical Indian Ocean and Maritime Continent and (B) tropical Pacific. Contours denote present-day space-time spectra in historical runs (1980–2014), while shading shows projected changes in space-time spectra under the SSP5-8.5 high-emission scenario (2065–2099). The top two panels are the schematic diagrams of regional space-time spectra analysis (see Methods), and the rectangular boxes denote the range of two regions. Black stippling represents a consistent sign of projected changes across >70% of the models. Contour intervals are 2.5 and 2.7 in (A), and 1.7 and 1.8 in (B), respectively. Units: 104 W2 m−4.Full size imageA recent study noted that under present-day conditions, enhanced diabatic heating during BSISO phases 6–7 over the tropical central-to-eastern Pacific can induce a Rossby wave train that propagates downstream over North America and affects local extremes22. In the following section, we examine the mechanism behind the projected eastward shift of the BSISO during phases 6–7 and its implications for downstream extreme events under a high-emission scenario.Causes of the BSISO Eastward ShiftIt has been reported that rapid SST warming over the tropical Pacific and the associated expansion of the warm pool since the 1980s have increased the MJO residence time over the tropical Pacific by 5–6 days47. There are also indications that future tropical Pacific SST warming would enhance MJO precipitation by strengthening the efficiency of vertical advective moistening associated with diabatic processes26,31,35. It suggests that wintertime MJO convection is sensitive to the SST warming patterns over tropical Pacific in the warming climate27. Here, we hypothesize that projected equatorial SST warming could also contribute to the eastward shift of the BSISO convective system. To test this hypothesis, we analyze the inter-model relationship between projected SST warming and BSISO longitudinal centroids under the high-emission scenario (Fig. 3). The results show that changes in the BSISO longitudinal centroid are associated with SST warming over the central-to-eastern tropical Pacific, suggesting that models projecting a stronger eastward shift of BSISO convection are characterized by enhanced SST warming in this region (Fig. 3A). This is further supported by a significant inter-model correlation between the SST warming over the central-to-eastern tropical Pacific and the eastward shift of the BSISO centroid (Fig. 3B; r = 0.63, p < 0.04).Fig. 3: Relationship between the eastward shift of BSISO convection and sea surface temperature (SST) warming over central-to-eastern tropical Pacific during boreal summer.A Inter-model regression of SST warming against the standardized longitudinal shift of BSISO centroid in 2065–2099 under SSP5-8.5 scenario. Stippling in (A) indicates the inter-model regression coefficients are significant at the 90% confidence level of the Student’s t test. B–D Inter-model scatter plots between area-weighted mean SST anomalies (SSTA) over central-to-eastern Pacific (8°S–8°N, 80°W–160°W, black box in (A); units: K), changes in mass-integrated \(\alpha\) from 850 hPa to 500 hPa over central-to-eastern Pacific (8°S–8°N, 80°W–160°W; unitless; see Methods), and fractional change of longitudinal shift of BSISO centroid relative to present-day conditions in 1980–2014 (units: %). The quantities in the top-right corner are the correlation coefficients. ***, **, and * denote statistically significant inter-model correlations at the 1%, 5%, and 10% levels, respectively.Full size imageWhat is the underlying physical link between SST warming over the central-to-eastern tropical Pacific and the eastward shift of BSISO convection? The SST warming patterns over the equatorial Pacific are important for regulating intraseasonal precipitation amplitude by altering vertical moisture advection and vertical heating profile26. To examine this effect, under the assumption of a weak temperature gradient in the tropics, we diagnose a nondimensional ratio (\(\alpha\)) defined as the ratio between vertical latent energy gradient (\({L}_{v}{\partial }_{p}q\)) and vertical dry static energy gradient (\({\partial }_{p}s\)) (see Methods). \(\alpha\) represents the efficiency with which a heating anomaly can moisten the tropical atmosphere through vertical advection26,27,48. In the present day, the JJA-mean \(\alpha\) is relatively large over the tropical northern Pacific (gray contours in Fig. 4A). Under the high-emission scenario, as SST warms over the central-to-eastern Pacific, the JJA-mean \(\alpha\) is projected to increase robustly over this region (Figs. 3C and 4A).Fig. 4: Projected changes in the environment favoring BSISO convection (∆α) under the high-emission scenario and contributions from the increased gradient of moisture (∆αq) and dry static energy (∆αs) (see Methods).A Relative difference of mass-weighted integrated \(\alpha\) from 850 to 500 hPa between the SSP5-8.5 (2065–2099) and historical runs (1980–2014). B same as (A) but for the composite of anomalous \(\alpha\) in BSISO phases 6–7. C, D Contributions of changes in moisture gradient and dry static energy to \(\triangle \alpha\). Gray contours in (A, C, D) show the present-day June-to-August-mean \(\alpha\) with intervals of 22 and 27, while green contours show the projected increases in sea surface temperature in 2065–2099 with interval of 3.4 K. White stippling denotes consistent sign of projected changes across > 70% of the models. Purple boxes refer to the extent of central-to-eastern Pacific. Units: % for shading, unitless for gray contours, and K for green contours.Full size imageTo quantify the relative contribution from moisture and dry static energy, we present the projected changes in \(\triangle {\alpha }_{q}\) (\(\triangle {\alpha }_{q}=\frac{\triangle {\partial }_{p}q}{{\partial }_{p}q}\), Fig. 4C) and \(\triangle {\alpha }_{s}\) (\(\triangle {\alpha }_{s}=-\frac{\triangle {\partial }_{p}s}{{\partial }_{p}s}\), Fig. 4D). The term \(\triangle {\alpha }_{q}\), associated with an increased vertical moisture gradient, shows a similar pattern to that of \(\triangle \alpha\), while \(\triangle {\alpha }_{s}\), associated with static stability, shows an opposite but weak change. The sum of these two terms follows the pattern of \(\triangle {\alpha }_{q}\), suggesting that the increased vertical moisture gradient dominates the increase in \(\alpha\).To further verify the connection between the mean-state changes and intraseasonal oscillation, we show the projected changes in the anomalous \(\alpha\) composite during BSISO phases 6–7 (Fig. 4B). The spatial pattern of changes in the anomalous \(\alpha\) composite during BSISO phases 6–7 is similar to that of the JJA-mean \(\alpha\) (Fig. 4A). Increases in \(\alpha\) with warming indicate that heating becomes more efficient at moistening the atmosphere compared to present-day conditions, triggering longer lasting and stronger convection26. Thus, increases in \(\alpha\) over the central-to-eastern Pacific under the high-emission scenario favor an eastward extension of convection, leading to the eastward shift of the BSISO convection system. This is further confirmed by a significant correlation between \(\alpha\) averaged over the central-to-eastern Pacific and the BSISO longitudinal centroid (Fig. 3D).Enhanced BSISO Teleconnection in a Changing ClimateThe projected eastward shift of the BSISO and its associated convective anomalies over the central-to-eastern tropical Pacific under a high-emission scenario can alter diabatic heating and the wave source (Fig. 1D). Shading in Fig. 5A, B shows the spatial patterns of diabatic heating anomalies during BSISO phases 6–7 for the historical and SSP5-8.5 scenarios, respectively. In the present-day climate, significant positive diabatic heating anomalies occur over the tropical western North Pacific and central-to-eastern Pacific (cyan box in Fig. 5A). Under the high-emission scenario, due to the BSISO eastward shift, positive diabatic heating anomalies over the central-to-eastern tropical Pacific are projected to strengthen robustly (Fig. 5B). This strengthened BSISO convection and diabatic heating will enhance the divergent flow in the upper levels, which can trigger Rossby waves more efficiently. Consequently, the Rossby wave source associated with the BSISO is projected to increase over the eastern tropical Pacific under the high-emission scenario (dashed contours in Fig. 5A, B; see Methods).Fig. 5: BSISO-related forcing, circulation and wave energy in historical and future climates.A Composites of the anomalous Rossby wave source (contours) and diabatic heating (shading) during BSISO phases 6–7 in historical runs in 1980–2014. B Projected changes in anomalous Rossby wave source and diabatic heating under the SSP5-8.5 scenario for 2065–2099, relative to the historical period. C, D Composite of geopotential height anomalies at 500 hPa during BSISO phases 6–7 (GPH500, shading; units: m), and June–August (JJA) mean zonal wind at 200 hPa (U200, blue and red contours, respectively; m s–1) in (C) historical and (D) SSP5-8.5 runs. Only positive U200 values are shown at 5 m s–1 intervals. Black solid and magenta dashed streamlines indicate the Rossby wave ray paths during the first 10 days after emanating from the central-to-eastern Pacific under historical and SSP5-8.5 scenarios, respectively. E Projected changes in anomalous GPH500 (shading), GPH250 (gray contours) during BSISO phases 6–7 and JJA-mean U200 (red contours) under SSP5-8.5 scenario. F, G Lead-lag cross-section of zonal-mean meridional wave activity flux (WAF) divergence anomalies at 500 hPa (contour; 105 m s–1) and U250 (shading; m s–1) anomalies averaged over 170°W–110°W during BSISO phases 6–7. H Projected changes in WAF anomalies at 500 hPa and U250 anomalies under SSP5-8.5. Stippling in (A, C, D, F, G) indicates where diabatic heating, GPH500 or U250 anomalies are statistically significant at the 10% level in >50% of models. Stippling in (B, E, H) denotes regions where more than 70% of models agree on the sign of projected changes in diabatic heating, GPH500 or U250. Slashing in (F–H) indicates regions where more than 70% of models agree on the sign of WAF divergence anomalies.Full size imageTo examine the projected changes in BSISO-related teleconnections, we compare the composites of geopotential height (GPH) anomalies at 500 hPa (GPH500) between the future and present-day climates (Fig. 5C, D). To account for the delayed response of midlatitude circulation to tropical convection anomalies mediated by the propagation of Rossby wave energy6,10, we conduct lagged composites spanning from day 0 to day +9, following Lubis22. In the present day, the anomalous GPH response during BSISO phases 6–7 shows an equivalent barotropic structure over the North Pacific and North America (Fig. 5C). The tropical central-to-eastern North Pacific exhibits a weak anticyclonic anomaly, followed by a cyclonic anomaly over the broader North Pacific, and an anticyclonic anomaly centered between British Columbia and the Gulf of Alaska, expanding into the PNW. This tripole pattern resembles a barotropic Rossby wave train emanating from the central-to-eastern tropical Pacific, as reported in observations22. Under the high-emission scenario, enhanced convection over the eastern tropical Pacific due to the BSISO eastward shift will robustly induce a stronger teleconnection than the present-day conditions (Fig. 5D), with an increase of area-average GPH500 (GPH250) variability over PNW by 71% (85%) (Fig. 5E).Additionally, the anticyclonic anomaly over the PNW is projected to expand northward and cover the entire northern North America under the high-emission scenario (Fig. 5D, E). This northward expansion is supported by the expanded background westerly flow. Previous studies indicated that the westerly flow associated with the central-to-eastern North Pacific subtropical jet acts as a waveguide for Rossby waves entering North America22,42,45,49. To explore the influence of the projected changes in westerly flow on BSISO teleconnections, we examined the westerly flow at the upper levels in both present-day and future climates (blue and red contours in Fig. 5C–E and shadings in Fig. 5F–H). Assisted by positive eddy feedback50,51, westerly flow at 200 hPa (U200) over North America is projected to shift poleward in the future warming climate compared to present-day conditions (Fig. 5E).Since the U200 location dominates the extent of the waveguide49,52, the northward expansion of U200 favors a more northward propagation of Rossby waves into NNA. To verify this hypothesis, we examine Rossby wave propagation using the ray tracing technique (Fig. 5C, D; see Methods). In present-day conditions, Rossby waves originating from tropical central-to-eastern North Pacific propagate northward to PNW and then meander eastward (black curves in Fig. 5C). Under the warming climate, the expansion of the westerly jet over North America favors a more northward propagation of Rossby waves into NNA (purple curves in Fig. 5D).To further verify the projected basic structures and dynamics of the BSISO-related wave train traveling downstream in a changing climate, we examine the composite of anomalous wave activity flux (WAF) divergence at 250 hPa, representing the direction of wave energy propagation53, and anomalous U250 (Fig. 5F–H). In the present day, significant U250 anomalies appear over the PNW since day +5 in BSISO phases 6–7, contributing to the convergence of local WAF and wave energy (dashed contours in Fig. 5F). In a changing climate, U250 anomalies will shift northward to NNA, leading to a northward expanded and strengthened WAF convergence (Fig. 5G, H). Thus, more northward wave energy over the Pacific coast of North America will feed into the NNA region under the high emission scenario than present-day conditions. Hence, the present-day BSISO teleconnection will strengthen and extend northward under the warmer climate, and the downstream stationary anticyclonic circulation will cover the entire NNA.Enhanced Heatwave/Wildfire Risk in North America’s High LatitudesRecent studies indicated an increase in summertime heat-dome-like structure at the seasonal scale over NNA driven by the warming patterns in the tropical Pacific by the end of the 21st century under a high-emission scenario40,54. Our results further reveal that due to the eastward shift of BSISO convection, projected anticyclonic circulation associated with BSISO teleconnection will enhance the seasonal-mean heat-dome structure (Fig. 5E). Furthermore, projected changes in background circulation will extend the coverage of the heat-dome structure over NNA. As large-scale subsidence of the heat-dome structure leads to cloud-free conditions and persistent downward radiation22,55,56, North America is expected to experience higher heatwave risk driven by enhanced teleconnections due to the BSISO eastward shift in the future.To quantify the influence of the BSISO eastward shift on NNA heatwave risk, we analyze the patterns of heatwave probability during BSISO phases 6–7 under the historical and SSP5-8.5 scenarios (Fig. 6A–C). In the present day, heatwave days during BSISO phases 6–7 account for 4–7% of the total summer days. Recent studies indicated contributions of land-atmosphere feedback to reinforce the heatwave57,58,59. Under the heat-dome anticyclonic circulation with increased solar radiation, soil moisture deficiency would further increase surface sensible heat flux and land-atmosphere feedback, heightening the heatwave occurrence. In a warming climate, the heat-dome days are expected to increase over the NNA region. Furthermore, the local mean soil moisture level is projected to decrease robustly due to the background warming and BSISO-related anticyclonic circulation, enhancing the land-atmosphere feedback (Supplementary Fig. S6). The joint effect of heat dome and land-atmosphere feedback will increase the heatwave probability. This probability is projected to increase to 6–9% under the high-emission scenario. The area-weighted mean heatwave probability over NNA is expected to increase by 23% (p < 0.001) in 2065–2099 relative to 1980–2014, while that over PNW will increase by 22% (p < 0.05).Fig. 6: BSISO-related increase in the heatwave probability and risk of large fire potential in the changing climate.A, B Heatwave probability over the 0–15-day period following BSISO phases 6–7 relative to the total summer days under the historical and high-emission (SSP5-8.5) scenarios, respectively (units: %). A heatwave occurs when the maximum near-surface air temperature exceeds the 90th percentile in (A) 1980–2014 under historical and (B) 2065–2099 under SSP5-8.5 (see Methods). Stippling in (A, B) denotes that heatwave probability is significant at the 10% level of >50% of the models. C Blue and red bars denote area-weighted mean values of heatwave probability over the Pacific Northwest of North America (PNW; 42°N–58°N, 107°W–135°W) and northern North America (NNA; 58°N–75°N, 120°W–155°W) under historical and SSP5-8.5 scenarios, respectively (left axis), while brown bars show the area-weighted mean probability of large fire potential (unit: %; right axis). Horizontal lines represent the multi-model means across eleven selected models, while bar charts show the inter-model spread. The quantities in (C) indicate the relative difference in heatwave probability between SSP5-8.5 and historical scenarios in percentages and significance levels. D Spatial pattern of wildfire risk ratio between SSP5-8.5 and historical scenarios. Stippling denotes the ratio larger than one across all models. The probability with values lower than 0.00001 in historical is masked as missing values.Full size imageBesides increased heatwave risk, the resultant warmer and drier surface conditions from large-scale subsidence tend to create a favorable environment for extreme wildfire events22,60,61,62,63. A previous study reported that positive vapor pressure deficit (VPD) anomalies during BSISO phases 6–7 significantly heightened the occurrence of wildfires in PNW22. Under the high-emission scenario, due to enhanced and northward-extended remote effects of BSISO, positive VPD anomalies are projected to intensify and extend across the entire NNA region under the SSP5-8.5 scenario, with an area-weighted mean of 0.102 (0.015 to 0.189) 10–1kPa. Compared to present-day conditions (0.027 [−0.011 to 0.065] 10–1 kPa), this represents a 3.8-fold increase in VPD anomalies over the NNA (Supplementary Fig. S6B). Under such a dry moisture condition, the risk of wildfire spread is expected to increase. Wildfire spread potential is quantified using the Lower Atmosphere Severity Index64,65 (see Methods). Under the SSP5-8.5 scenario, during BSISO phases 6–7, the area-weighted mean probability of large fire potential in the PNW is projected to reach 2.84% (2.64% to 3.04%), representing a 59% increase compared to present-day conditions (1.79%) (brown bar in Fig. 6C). Notably, the probability over NNA region is projected to rise to 0.71%, an approximately fivefold increase relative to present-day conditions (0.11%). Figure 6D shows the ratio of large fire potential between the historical and high-emission scenarios. The risk of wildfire spread is projected to be 2–7 times higher across much of NNA and PNW during BSISO phases 6–7, with area-weighted mean values of 3.5 (1.4–6.0) times over NNA and 2.2 (1.1–4.2) times over PNW. The increase is particularly pronounced in areas covered by boreal forests, including southern Alaska, Yukon, and British Columbia. The surge in wildfire activity is expected to have lasting effects on forest ecosystems and terrestrial carbon storage.DiscussionUsing eleven CMIP6 models that skillfully simulate the mean large-state climate patterns, BSISO mode, and BSISO life cycle, our results reveal a robust eastward shift of the BSISO convective system to the central-to-eastern Pacific under the high-emission scenario in 2065–2099. The finding is supported by an increase in subseasonal variability over the tropical Pacific and a decrease over the Indian Ocean. This eastward shift is predominantly driven by increased convective moistening efficiency associated with equatorial Pacific SST warming. Stronger BSISO convection over the central-to-eastern Pacific, coupled with the northward expansion of the westerly jet in a warmer climate, induces a teleconnection wave train of greater magnitude (~71%) reaching further north over North America. Consequently, during BSISO phases 6–7, heatwave risks are projected to rise by ~23%, while the risk of large fire potential is expected to be 3.5 times higher than present. These findings are summarized and illustrated in Fig. 7.Fig. 7: Schematic diagram illustrating projected changes in the BSISO convective system and its teleconnection influence on downstream heatwave and wildfire risks under a high-emission scenario.In a warmer climate, the eastward shift of the BSISO during phases 6–7 enhances convection and diabatic heating over the tropical central-to-eastern Pacific, intensifying the Rossby wave train that propagates downstream toward North America. With a northward expansion of the westerly jet serving as a waveguide, the teleconnection pattern extends further north, covering much of northern North America. This leads to a stronger heat-dome-like anticyclonic circulation, increasing regional risks of heatwaves and large wildfire potential through enhanced solar radiation and vapor-pressure deficit.Full size imageTo assess how BSISO-induced heatwave risk compares to the overall increases in summertime heat extremes under a warming climate, we analyze the absolute changes in BSISO-related heatwave intensity. Heatwave intensity is quantified by the anomalous maximum temperature averaged on the days exceeding the 90th percentile in the historical and SSP5-8.5 scenarios, respectively. Our results show significant increases of 0.85 K and 1.08 K in the BSISO-induced heatwave intensity over the PNW and NNA regions, respectively (Fig. S7). Based on the climatological 90th percentile levels of daily maximum surface air temperature, the enhancement during BSISO phases 6–7 is greater than the climatological warming of daily maximum surface air temperature in the PNW (0.60 K), and nearly equivalent in the NNA (1.05 K vs. 1.08 K). This highlights the major role of the projected eastward shift of BSISO convection in intensifying regional heatwaves. Furthermore, how would eastward shift of BSISO convection affect the changes in other heatwave characteristics, including extent and duration, remains an open question and needs to be explored in the future research.Our study highlights the dominant role of the El Niño-like warming pattern in driving the projected eastward shift of the BSISO. Previous works have shown that uncertainty in SST warming patterns over the central-to-eastern Pacific is largely linked to present-day model biases in ocean circulation, cloud-radiation feedbacks, and climatological SST66,67,68. Recent studies, after accounting for these biases, consistently support an El Niño-like warming response across models66,69,70,71,72, contributing to an intensified heat-dome-like anticyclonic circulations over NNA regions40,54. Thus, to some extent, these findings lend confidence to our results that the BSISO convective system is likely to shift eastward in a warming climate, amplifying the risk of extreme heat and wildfires over North America.Such robust changes in tropical-induced teleconnections imply an increased predictability beyond a week for summertime conditions in North America. Although accurately simulating BSISO propagation remains challenging due to the diversified propagation forms73,74,75,76, recent studies noted that the characteristic of BSISO eastward propagation over tropical Pacific is more predictable than others77. Given the significant contribution of BSISO convection over the central-to-eastern Pacific (phases 6–7) to heatwave predictability over North America22,23, the future eastward shift of BSISO suggests that subseasonal prediction of heatwaves and wildfires could benefit from accurate simulation and prediction of BSISO.In summary, the results of this study not only fill the knowledge gap regarding the projected teleconnection of BSISO on the mid-high latitudes during boreal summer but also provide implications for improving subseasonal predictions of heatwave and wildfire risks in the warming climate.MethodsDataThe historical and SSP5-8.5 experiments of eleven climate models are used to project changes in the BSISO convective system and teleconnection under anthropogenic warming78,79. Present-day and future climates are defined as 1980–2014 in historical run and 2065–2099 under SSP5-8.5 scenario, respectively. The eleven models were selected based on their ability to simulate large-scale mean-state patterns and BSISO properly. A summary of the selected models, indicated by triangles in the metric plot (Supplementary Fig. S1), is provided in Supplementary Table S1 with their basic information.To evaluate model performance in simulating mean-state patterns, several monthly observational datasets are used. The monthly gridded observational precipitation datasets used in this study are 1) the Global Precipitation Climatology Project version 2.2 (GPCP v2.2)80 and 2) the Climate Prediction Center (CPC) Merged Analysis of Precipitation version 12.01 (CMAP v1201)81. Both observational datasets have a spatial resolution of 2.5°\(\times\)2.5° from 1979 to the present. The spatial pattern over land is consistently represented by these two datasets, while over the ocean, there is an artificial decreasing trend in the CMAP data due to sampling error over small islands82,83,84. Therefore, we use only the GPCP precipitation data over the ocean, although we use the arithmetic mean of the GPCP and CMAP data over land. The monthly gridded observational sea surface temperature (SST) datasets used in this study are 1) the Hadley Centre Global Sea Ice and SST version 1.1 with resolution of 1°\(\times\)1° (HadISST v1.1)85 and 2) the NOAA extended reconstructed SST version 5 with resolution of 2°\(\times\)2° (ERSSTv5)86. We also use monthly reanalysis datasets of the fifth major global reanalysis produced by the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ERA5), with a spatial resolution of 0.25°\(\times\)0.25° and 137 levels from the surface up to 80 km from 1958 to the present87.To calculate the BSISO indices and evaluate simulation skills of BSISO mode and life cycle, we use the daily interpolated OLR data from NOAA/NESDIS88, spanning from 1979 to 2020 and with a spatial resolution of 2.5°\(\times\)2.5°. We also use daily low-level zonal wind and vertical velocity at 500 hPa from ERA5.The observational and reanalysis data from 1980 to 2014 have been used. All the data has been re-gridded to 2.5°\(\times\)2.5° grids using first-order conservative interpolation, except for the circulation patterns, which are re-gridded using bilinear interpolation. When we calculate the BSISO centroid, the precipitation data is re-gridded to 1°\(\times\)1° grids using first-order conservative interpolation.In our analysis, we focus on the multimodel ensemble mean. Besides, we further analyze the robustness and significance of the response to the warming climate. Robustness refers to a consistent sign of projected changes across more than 70% of the models. Statistical significance is assessed using a Student’s t-test. Anomalies are considered statistically significant if they exceed the 10% significance level in at least 50% of the models.BSISO definitionsTo ensure the robustness of the eastward shift in the BSISO convective system, two BSISO indices are utilized in this study. The first one is the daily bimodal index computed using methodology outlined in ref. 6. This index accurately captures the coherent northward and eastward propagation of the BSISO and is better suited for tracking the global BSISO-associated convection than alternative indices5,14,22,89. An extended empirical orthogonal function (EEOF) analysis of OLR anomaly in the tropics with three time lags (–10, –5, and 0 days) is conducted to identify the spatial-temporal patterns of the BSISO modes during the JJA period. Before the EEOF analysis, to extract intraseasonal variability from the daily OLR anomaly, we apply a Lanczos band-pass filter with cut-off periods of 25 and 90 days and with 141 weights. The first two leading principal components (PCs) are calculated by projecting the intraseasonal OLR anomaly onto each EEOF mode. The BSISO is classified as active (inactive) if its amplitude is greater (lower) than 1, where amplitude is defined as \(\sqrt{{PC}{1}^{2}+{PC}{2}^{2}}\). The two-dimensional phase space constructed by PC1 and PC2 is then divided into eight equally partitioned sections, each corresponding to one of the eight distinct phases of the BSISO.Besides, we also compute real-time multivariate BSISO index, following ref. 4. The definition of real-time multivariate index is similar with that of bimodal index, except that the real-time multivariate BSISO index uses MV-EOF analysis of daily mean OLR and 850-hPa zonal wind (U850) anomalies over the Asian summer monsoon region (10°S–40°N, 40°E–160°E).Based on bimodal and real-time multivariate BSISO indices, to isolate discrete and robust signals in boreal summer, we only select the BSISO events which meet the following criteria: (1) the BSISO indices retain their amplitude greater than 1 for at least five days, and (2) the start and end dates of events occur in JJA. Two consecutive BSISO phases with similar convective patterns are combined, viz. 8–1, 2–3, 4–5, and 6–722.The conclusions in this study are not sensitive to the choices of BSISO indices. Hence, the results in the main text are mainly based on bimodal index unless otherwise noted, while the results based on real-time multivariate BSISO index are shown in the Supplementary.Following refs. 27, 39, the eastward shift of the BSISO itself is measured by the longitudinal centroid (\({\theta }_{{BSISO}}\)) of the tropical BSISO-phase-composited precipitation fields, over the domain of 5°S–15°N, 60°E–150°W though. \({\theta }_{{BSISO}}\) is defined as$${\theta }_{{BSISO}}=\frac{{\int }_{60^\circ E}^{150^\circ W}{\int }_{5^\circ S}^{15^\circ N}{P{\rm{d}}}\varphi \theta \theta }{{\int }_{60^\circ E}^{150^\circ W}{\int }_{5^\circ S}^{15^\circ N}{P{\rm{d}}}\varphi {\rm{d}}\theta }$$
                    (1)
                where \(\theta\) is the longitude and \(\varphi\) is the latitude. Similarly, the latitudinal centroid (\({\varphi }_{{BSISO}}\)) is defined as:$${\varphi }_{{BSISO}}=\frac{{\int }_{60^\circ E}^{150^\circ W}{\int }_{5^\circ S}^{15^\circ N}P\varphi {\rm{d}}\varphi {\rm{d}}\theta }{{\int }_{60^\circ E}^{150^\circ W}{\int }_{5^\circ S}^{15^\circ N}{P{\rm{d}}}\varphi {\rm{d}}\theta }$$
                    (2)
                BSISO-related EvaluationsIt was reported that both the mean states and the intraseasonal oscillation must be well represented to reproduce the correct teleconnection patterns42. Hence, we evaluate the model performance of mean-state patterns, modes and life cycle of BSISO convective system (Supplementary Fig. S1) using the following formula:$${Score}={\left(1+{PCC}\right)}^{2}/(\sigma +{1/\sigma )}^{2}$$
                    (3)
                where PCC denotes the uncentered pattern correlation coefficient between the observation and the model, and \(\sigma\) denotes the ratio of the spatial standard deviation between the observation and the model. To allow comparison among different metrics, the skill scores are homogenized:$$S=({Score}-{Scor}{e}_{\min })/({Scor}{e}_{\max }-{Scor}{e}_{\min })$$
                    (4)
                The evaluated metrics of mean states include 1) mean precipitation (Summer Pr.), sea surface temperature (Summer Trop. SST), specific humidity at 1000hPa (Summer Trop. Humidity), and vertical wind shear (Ver. Wind Shear) over Indo-Pacific basin (30°S–30°N, 40°E–180°) in boreal summer, and zonal wind at 200 hPa in Northern Hemisphere (0°–80°N, 0°–360°; U200) in boreal summer. We compute the skill score using the mean-state pattern in 1979–2014.The evaluated metrics of BSISO modes include the first two leading modes of extended empirical orthogonal function analysis of tropical OLR. We compute the averaged PCCs and \(\sigma\) of each model against those in observations across three time lags (–10, –5, and 0 days), and then calculate the averaged PCCs and \(\sigma\) across the first two leading modes. Finally, we compute the skill score based on the averaged PCCs and \(\sigma\).The evaluated metrics of BSISO life cycle include time-longitude patterns of BSISO-phase-composited OLR anomalies averaged over equator (5°S–5°N) and averaged over NH tropics (15°N–20°N), as well as time-latitude patterns of BSISO-phase-composited zonal-mean OLR anomalies averaged over central Indian Ocean (71.25°N ~ 83.75°E). The time-longitude and time-latitude patterns of OLR anomalies from 40°E to 120°W and from 30°S to 30°N are used to calculate the skill scores, respectively.Here, we only evaluate the model performance of the mean states and the BSISO life cycle. Although our results show that projected changes in BSISO teleconnections are dominated by the SST warming patterns over tropical Pacific, we do not include present-day SST warming trends in the list of evaluated metrics. The observed SST trends were driven by internal variability associated with the Pacific decadal oscillation90,91 and anthropogenic forcings of aerosols or ozone depletion92,93,94. In the future projections with decreasing aerosol emission and ozone recovery, the projected SST warming patterns would be driven by the anthropogenic greenhouse gases72,93. The performance of present-day SST trends may not represent the simulation skills of CMIP6 models.Regional space-time power spectraTo identify the location changes in BSISO convection, regional space-time power spectra of OLR and zonal wind at 850 hPa (U850) localized by longitudinal sectors are calculated following the tapering method from refs. 95, 96. The OLR and U850 data are tapered in time and space using a Hann window centered at 96 days along the temporal direction. The time window is chosen to be larger than the period of the lowest frequencies of BSISO. The longitudinal sector from the tropical Indian Ocean to the Maritime Continent is 40°E–140°E with a central longitude of 90°E, while the longitudinal sector of the tropical Pacific is 140°E–140°W with a central longitude of 180°. The maximum time window is 96 days. The latitudinal averages for OLR and U850 data are calculated from 10°S to 25°N.A Fourier transform in time and longitude is calculated using the windowed data. For a given longitudinal sector, date, planetary wave number (k) and frequency in cycles per day (\(\omega\)), we derive a time series of space-time spectral power by sliding the temporal time window throughout the entire record. Specifically, for every wave number on the ordinate, the frequency on the abscissa is given by:$$\overline{\omega (k)}=\frac{\sum {r}^{2}(k,\omega )\omega (k)}{\sum {r}^{2}(k,\omega )}$$

We begin with dry static energy budget:$$\frac{\partial s}{\partial t}+{\boldsymbol{v}}\cdot \nabla s+\omega \frac{\partial s}{\partial p}={Q}_{1}$$
                    (6)
                where s denotes dry static energy (cpT + gz, cp: heat capacity at constant pressure; T: air temperature; z: geopotential height), \({\boldsymbol{v}}\) denotes horizontal wind, and \(\omega\) denotes vertical velocity. \({Q}_{1}\) is apparent heat source. Under the assumption of the weak temperature gradient in the tropics, large-scale vertical advection of s (\(\omega \frac{\partial s}{\partial p}\)) approximately balance \({Q}_{1}\), and Eq. (6) can be rearranged to be$$\omega \cong {Q}_{1}/\frac{\partial s}{\partial p}$$

                In the context of the BSISO, intraseasonal variations in large-scale vertical motion are a direct dynamical response to variations in apparent heating, given that effective gravity wave adjustment occurs on spatial (temporal) scales much larger (shorter) than intraseasonal variations in apparent heating98.                     (8)

                where \(\triangle {\alpha }_{q}=\triangle ({\partial }_{p}q)/{\partial }_{p}q\) and \(\triangle {\alpha }_{s}=-\triangle ({\partial }_{p}s)/{\partial }_{p}s\).Diagnostic methods for the Rossby wave source and propagationThe variation of quasi-stationary waves over northern North America may be preceded by an upstream Rossby wave train triggered by the BSISO convection over central-to-eastern tropical Pacific. A systematic approach to modeling monthly maximum temperature and total rainfall in Kenya
                    Kevin Otieno1, Linda Chaba1,2, Collins Odhiambo1,3 & …Bernard Omolo1,4 Show authors

Scientific Reports

volume 15, Article number: 31758 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate and Earth system modellingHydrologyStatistics

AbstractGoodness of fit (GOF) test approaches for selecting probability distributions of climatic variables are pervasive in the statistical literature. However, a combined approach of multiple tests remains underutilized despite evidence supporting their improved precision. Increased erratic climatic conditions pose severe threats to economic stability, necessitating robust statistical methods for climate modeling. To address this need, this study evaluates probability distributions for climatic variables using a comprehensive approach that combines multiple tests. A scoring system ranked each distribution’s performance across tests, with a composite score indicating the best fit. To assess robustness, sensitivity analysis on the best-performing distribution examined the influence of partitioning data into different segments (block sizes). The results show a generalized extreme value (GEV) distribution consistently outperforming other temperature and rainfall data distributions across multiple metrics. Extended block sizes capture long-term climatic patterns but introduce greater uncertainty due to fewer data points, while shorter block sizes tend to overfit. Intermediate block sizes provide a balance, producing reliable parameter estimates and stable return levels. These findings underscore the importance of selecting suitable block sizes and confirm the robustness of the GEV distribution for climate modeling. The study contributes to improved methodologies for risk assessment and climate adaptation strategies, particularly in regions such as Kenya.

                        IntroductionKenya’s increasing exposure to the effects of climate variability is a pressing issue, especially with erratic rainfall patterns and rising high-temperature patterns significantly affecting its key sectors. Agriculture, a backbone of Kenya’s economy1,2, is particularly vulnerable, as unpredictable weather disrupts planting and harvesting cycles, reduces yields, and exacerbates food insecurity. Infrastructure, too, faces challenges, with extreme weather events such as floods and droughts causing damage to roads, bridges, and other critical systems. The cumulative effect of these climate-induced challenges undermines the country’s overall economic stability, highlighting the urgent need for robust mitigation and adaptation strategies.The effects of climate variability are particularly evident in regions like Marsabit, where prolonged droughts and heavy rainfall lead to severe consequences. Droughts reduce water availability, hinder crop growth, and limit pastures, leading to crop failures and livestock losses, exacerbating food insecurity3,4,5. In contrast, intense rainfall causes soil erosion, farmland flooding, and infrastructure damage, imposing significant financial burdens on the government for repairs and diverting resources from development projects.These recurring events underscore the urgent need for sustainable strategies, such as climate-resilient agricultural practices, improved water management systems, and robust infrastructure design. Investments in early warning systems and community-based adaptation measures are also critical to mitigating the impacts on vulnerable populations.A deeper understanding of climate variability, such as rainfall and temperature, can be achieved through probability distributions, which provide valuable tools to analyze climate patterns6. Globally, researchers have identified region- and time-dependent distributions for these variables, with models such as GEV, Gamma, log-normal, and Weibull frequently recommended for climatic data. Notable studies include those by Sharma and Singh7, Dzupire et al.8, Athulya and James9, Ozonur et al.10, Ximenes et al.11, Hussain et al.12, Singirankabo and Iyamuremye13 and Agbonaye and Izinyon14. For example, Ximenes et al.11 found Gamma and Weibull to be optimal for monthly precipitation in Northeast Brazil, while Douka and Karacostas15 identified GEV and log-normal as suitable for extreme precipitation in Thessaloniki, Greece. The differences in the probability distributions between11 and15 can be attributed to different geographical locations; Greece is located between \((40^\circ \text 37' N, 22^\circ \text 95' E)\) and northeast Brazil is \((34^\circ \text 47' N, 48^\circ \text 45' W)\). Their work on these regions also employed different periods; Greece’s data comprised monthly precipitation records from 1988 to 2017, whereas the study on Northeast Brazil used hourly rainfall data from 1947 to 2003. These studies and a summary in Table 1 demonstrate the importance of selecting appropriate probability distributions for accurate climate modeling.Table 1 Literature results of probability density functions (PDF) fitted to rainfall data.Full size tableExtensive research has also been conducted to identify the best-fitting probability distributions for temperature data. Key studies include those by Athulya and James9, Dzupire et al.8, Hasan22, Hossain23, Hussain et al.12 and Ozonur et al.10. These studies have explored various distributions, including the normal, log-normal, Gamma, and Weibull distributions. For instance, Hussain et al.12 identified the Generalized Pareto (GP), Extreme Value (EV), and GEV models as suitable for modeling temperature data. Similarly, Hasan22 employed ten continuous distributions, including the exponential, Gamma, Log-Gamma, Beta, normal, log-normal, Erlang, power function, Rayleigh, and Weibull distributions, with the Beta distribution emerging as the best fit for the temperature data.This study aims to identify the most appropriate probability distributions for modeling monthly maximum temperatures and total monthly rainfall in Kenya. The analysis is based on a comprehensive data set covering the last 73 years, capturing the impacts of recent climatic changes. By incorporating these extensive and up-to-date data, the study ensures that the models account for evolving climate patterns. For instance, accurate descriptions of climatic data provide a better understanding of the probability distributions of maximum temperatures and total rainfall, which helps capture the frequency and intensity of climatic events, such as heat waves and heavy downpours. These models also enhance predictive capabilities by leveraging historical trends and recent shifts, improving forecasting accuracy and facilitating better preparation for future climatic scenarios. Additionally, by identifying the underlying distributions, the study supports data-driven decision-making, providing a critical foundation for risk assessment and resource allocation in agriculture, water management, and disaster response sectors.The study makes a significant contribution to modeling climatic events through three key focus areas. First, it provides a comprehensive theoretical framework for understanding and applying statistical distributions in hydrology and climate studies. The framework offers precise definitions of commonly used distributions, facilitating their identification and application to various climatic datasets. It also includes robust parameter estimation methodologies that ensure accurate modeling of climatic variables. Furthermore, the study outlines strategies for selecting extreme values tailored to specific extreme value distributions, enabling the precise focus on significant climatic events.Second, the research emphasizes the application of GOF tests to identify the most suitable probability distributions for climatic data. Detailed discussions on the implementation of GOF tests enhance the accuracy and reliability of the models. This methodological rigor improves the alignment of models with observed data and bolsters their credibility for practical applications in risk assessment and decision-making.Lastly, we emphasized the significance of temporal pattern analysis through block size selection, a crucial factor in statistical modeling that directly impacts the capture of temporal patterns in climatic data. We conducted a sensitivity analysis to assess the impact of varying block sizes on the GEV distribution. This analysis combined graphical methods, GOF tests, return level estimates for various periods, and confidence intervals. By examining the effect of block size on model performance and extremal forecast, this section provides valuable insights into the stability and reliability of the GEV distribution across varying temporal resolutions.The paper is structured as follows. “Methods” section provides a detailed description of the data, the procedure for selecting candidate probability distributions, parameter estimation methods, and the implementation of GOF tests, including the combined approach of multiple GoF tests. “Results and discussion” section presents summary statistics, results from the selection of candidate distributions, findings from the GoF tests, and insights from the sensitivity analysis. Finally, “Conclusion” section concludes the paper by summarizing the key findings and their implications for climate modeling and risk assessment.MethodsDataThe monthly maximum temperature (Tmax) and total precipitation (Prep) data for Kenya, covering the period 1950–2022, were sourced from the World Bank Climate Change Knowledge Portal24. The precipitation data (Prep), measured in millimeters, represents the total accumulation of monthly rainfall. This provides a comprehensive measure of rainfall intensity and distribution across different months. The temperature data (Tmax), recorded in degrees Celsius, captures the highest daily maximum temperature observed each month, offering valuable insights into extreme temperature events.Selection of candidate probability distributionsA review of existing literature identified probability distributions commonly applied in hydrological studies: exponential, Gamma, Weibull, log-normal, logistic, Gumbel, GPD, and GEV, as referenced by7,8,9,10,11,12,14,16,17,18,20. Similarly, for temperature data, these distributions, in addition to a normal distribution, were identified as suitable candidates, supported by findings from22 and other related studies. Table 2 describes each probability distribution function. These distributions were selected due to their suitability in modeling skewed, heavy-tailed, or extreme data characteristics commonly found in climatic datasets. The Cullen and Frey graph25 was used to preliminarily assess the shape characteristics of the data, guiding the selection of appropriate distributions for further analysis.Parameter estimationIn statistical modeling, parameter estimation is essential due to the typically unknown nature of most model parameters. Commonly employed methods include the Method of Moments, L-moments, Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE), and LH-moments, as noted in studies by Al Mamoon and Rahman6 and Haddad and Rahman26. In this paper, we employ the MLE method for parameter estimation across the analyzed distributions, as it is one of the most widely applied and robust methods. MLE is favored for its consistency and efficiency, particularly in large samples, as it maximizes the likelihood of the observed data and often yields more reliable results compared to other methods such as Moments, L-moments, and LH-moments, particularly in terms of asymptotic properties. Research, including foundational studies by Fisher27, Zong28 and Naghettini29, has demonstrated that MLE’s variance and bias are comparatively low, thereby enhancing its suitability across a broad range of distributions. These qualities render MLE exceptionally reliable for environmental datasets, including temperature and rainfall measurements, where precision and robustness are critical.Goodness of fit testsThe suitability of each probability distribution was assessed using a suite of GOF tests, including the Kolmogorov-Smirnov (KS), Anderson-Darling (AD), Cramer-von Mises (CvM), and Chi-Square tests. These tests evaluate the alignment between theoretical and empirical data, with KS tests focusing on overall distributional fit15,30, AD and CvM emphasizing tail behavior15,26,31,32,33, and Chi-Square examining frequency alignment19. Additional evaluation was performed using Akaike Information Criteria (AIC) and Bayesian Information Criteria (BIC) to balance model complexity and fit10,12,22,26, along with Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) to quantify predictive accuracy14.Comprehensive scoring methodologyThe literature indicates a lack of suitable GOF tests designed to effectively distinguish between empirical and theoretical distributions34. Numerous studies have shown that the best-fit probability distribution can vary significantly between different regions, even for the same variable32. In response to these challenges, we adopt a comprehensive scoring methodology, as outlined in previous studies14,17,22,35. This method employs an integrated scoring approach that incorporates multiple GOF tests, information criteria, and graphical analyses to ensure a robust selection of the optimal probability distribution model. Each distribution model is subjected to several GOF tests, with a scoring system applied whereby the best-performing model in each test receives the highest rank. To enhance the rigor of the selection process, each model’s rank is determined independently for each GOF test and then aggregated across all tests to produce a composite score. For graphical assessments, rankings are informed by visual inspection of density plots and quantile-quantile (Q–Q) plots, providing additional insight into the best-fitting model.Table 2 Description of various probability distribution functions.Full size tableResults and discussionThis section provides statistical results from the analysis. Block size refers to a series of independent groups of observations of a particular length38. According to Coles and Coles38, block sizes are often selected to capture a specific period. In this work, the block sizes included annual, seasonal, monthly, 5-year, 10-year, 12-month moving averages, 6-month intervals, and 4-month intervals. Annual blocks, where maximum values were extracted per year, followed the methodologies outlined in38,41. Seasonal blocks were based on quarterly aggregations, as indicated by42 and41. Monthly blocks were used to capture monthly maxima, as discussed in43 and42. For longer-term patterns, multi-year blocks of 5-year and 10-year intervals were established, consistent with approaches adopted in studies such as44. A 12-month moving average window assessed rolling maxima, highlighting shifts in trends. Event-based blocks focused on the most extreme events by isolating total rainfall above the 95th percentile following the techniques used in45. For intermediate seasonality, semi-annual blocks were divided each year into January–June and July–December intervals, consistent with approaches used by42,43,46. Furthermore, a regional seasonal classification for Kenya was used to account for local climatic variations, with blocks corresponding to the “Hot and Dry”, “Long Rainy”, “Cool”, and “Short Rainy” seasons, building on the framework proposed by47. In contrast, mid-range blocks, such as monthly, quarterly, event-based, and seasonal, yielded significant positive shape parameters, reflecting the heavy-tailed Frechet class of distributions with well-defined extremal patterns. This is in agreement with Moccia et al.33 although the findings of Onwuegbuche et al.48 and Singirankabo et al.37 revealed that Gumbel is the optimal distribution. The location and scale parameters were consistently significant \((p < 0.05)\) across all block sizes, indicating reliable estimation of central tendency and variability. For temperature data, location and scale parameters were also consistently significant across all blocks, confirming stable estimates of central tendency and variability. However, the shape parameter was not significant for the 5-year, 10-year, and event-based models, indicating uncertainty in tail estimates, which is likely due to the limited number of data points or the irregular occurrence of extreme events. In addition, we have identified the optimal block size for the GEV distribution using return levels across different periods, as well as log-likelihood, AIC, and BIC. Insights from GOF tests highlighted that the GEV, Gamma, and log-normal distributions were well-suited for both maximum temperature and total rainfall datasets, as they consistently aligned with empirical data. On the other hand, distributions such as uniform, Weibull, and logistic showed a poor fit across multiple metrics, underscoring their limitations in capturing the complexities of climatic variables. The GEV distribution emerged as the optimal model for rainfall and temperature data, consistently outperforming others in key metrics such as the AIC, BIC, and RMSE. It also demonstrated superior performance in GOF tests, including the KS, AD, and CVM tests. This strong performance affirms the robustness of the GEV distribution in modeling climatic extremes and its capacity to provide reliable insights into long-term trends.Block size analysis revealed the effectiveness of longer temporal aggregations, such as 10-year and 5-year blocks, which produced stable and high return levels across return periods, effectively capturing long-term extreme trends. However, these longer blocks increased uncertainty in parameter estimates due to fewer data points. In contrast, intermediate blocks, such as quarterly and seasonal, struck a balance by capturing seasonal variations while maintaining stability and reliable parameter estimates with moderate AIC and BIC values. High-frequency blocks, such as monthly and 12-month moving averages, although rich in data, exhibited higher AIC and BIC values, suggesting potential overfitting and inefficiency in representing extreme values.The results of this study are important for Kenya and the East African region, as the adopted methodology can be applied. The comprehensive GOF tests also enhance forecasting temperature and rainfall data, which is crucial for risk assessment and the development of climate adaptation strategies. With this knowledge, predictions and preparations for catastrophic events, such as floods, droughts, or rising temperatures, can be enhanced. With better forecasts, policymakers and the government can improve infrastructure for water catchment systems and enhance agricultural activities through proper planning and disaster preparedness.However, a key limitation of this study is its focus on individual probability distributions for temperature and rainfall without explicitly addressing the interdependence between these variables. Since temperature and rainfall are inherently related, accurate risk assessments and effective climate adaptation strategies require consideration of their associations. Extensive research has been conducted on the dependence between temperature and rainfall; therefore, future studies should prioritize exploring dependence structures within a multivariate framework using the fitted probability distributions identified in this study. Advanced approaches such as copula models or joint distribution analyses could provide deeper insights into the interactions between these variables, particularly under extreme climatic conditions. Such efforts would significantly enhance the reliability of climate models and their applicability to integrated risk assessment frameworks.To build on this work, future research should focus on applying this methodology at finer spatial scales using real datasets from various regions in Kenya. Conducting probability distribution analyses at regional levels, incorporating block size analysis, and integrating data from multiple weather stations could yield region-specific insights into seasonal rainfall patterns, further informing targeted climate adaptation strategies. From a policy perspective, the results underscore the need for data-driven strategies that take into account both individual and joint variability of climatic variables. Policymakers should leverage these insights to design robust adaptation measures, such as enhancing agricultural planning, improving water resource management, and enhancing infrastructure resilience tailored to Kenya’s specific climate challenges.

items.title: Intelligenza Artificiale (AI) ed energia: futuri consumi in crescita e nuove opportunità di efficienza
items.description: L’intelligenza artificiale divora energia, e lo fa con una crescente voracità. Secondo un report dell’Agenzia Internazionale dell’Energia (IEA), l’ado
items.body:
Intelligenza Artificiale (AI) ed energia: futuri consumi in crescita e nuove opportunità di efficienza

26.08.2025 -                                 Energia, Fonti Rinnovabili, Efficienza Energetica

condividi:

L’intelligenza artificiale divora energia, e lo fa con una crescente voracità.

Secondo un report dell’Agenzia Internazionale dell’Energia (IEA), l’adozione massiccia di sistemi come ChatGPT, Midjourney e altri modelli AI sta facendo impennare i consumi energetici globali in modo preoccupante.

I data center, cuore pulsante dell’AI, sono destinati a raddoppiare il consumo elettrico entro il 2030, trasformandosi in uno dei principali motori della domanda energetica mondiale.

Ma se da un lato l’intelligenza artificiale consuma enormi quantità di energia, dall’altro può diventare un alleato prezioso nell’ottimizzarne l’uso.

Fonte: pexels.com

Intelligenza Artificiale (AI) ed energia: nei data center consumi energetici molto importanti

945 terawattora: è la quantità di elettricità che i data center consumeranno nel 2030.

Ogni risposta generata dall’AI richiede migliaia di processori ad alta intensità energetica, come GPU e chip tensoriali, che assorbono molta più energia rispetto ai processori tradizionali.

I consumi dei data center sono già in crescita del 12% annuo dal 2017, quattro volte più rapida rispetto all’aumento della domanda globale di elettricità.

Grandi aziende come Google, Microsoft e Meta stanno investendo miliardi in nuove infrastrutture dotate di sistemi avanzati di raffreddamento, necessari per gestire il calore generato dai processori AI, oltre a sistemi per il recupero del calore a fini civili.

Il lato positivo dell’Intelligenza Artificiale (AI): fonti energetiche rinnovabili e sostenibilità

Nonostante l’impatto ambientale, l’AI potrebbe diventare parte della soluzione.

Secondo le previsioni:

il 50% della crescita dei consumi energetici AI sarà coperto da energie rinnovabili.

le big tech stanno siglando accordi per acquistare energia pulita, con l’obiettivo di ridurre la propria impronta carbonica.

ricercatori e sviluppatori lavorano a modelli più efficienti dal punto di vista energetico, riducendo consumi senza compromettere le performance.

Fonte: pexels.com

AI e domanda elettrica globale: una sfida per le reti di trasmissione elettrica

Entro il 2030, circa il 20% della crescita della domanda elettrica nei paesi avanzati sarà attribuibile all’intelligenza artificiale.

Sì tratta di un dato che sta già mettendo in difficoltà le utility elettriche in aree ad alta concentrazione tecnologica come la Silicon Valley. 
La costruzione di nuove linee elettriche richiede anni, e senza interventi strutturali fino al 20% dei progetti di data center potrebbe subire ritardi.

AI per l’efficienza energetica: un potenziale di risparmio energetico da 300 TWh

Se da un lato l’AI consuma, dall’altro può farci risparmiare energia.

I sistemi di machine learning permettono di:

ottimizzare i consumi degli edifici, riducendo sprechi di climatizzazione e illuminazione.

migliorare la gestione delle reti elettriche intelligenti.

integrare meglio le energie rinnovabili intermittenti.

accelerare la ricerca di nuovi materiali per batterie e pannelli solari.

Il potenziale risparmio stimato è di 300 terawattora, un valore significativo per contrastare i consumi crescenti.

Conclusioni

L’intelligenza artificiale è una tecnologia a doppio taglio: grande consumatrice di energia, ma al tempo stesso strumento chiave per ottimizzarne l’uso.

La sfida sarà bilanciare questi due aspetti, garantendo uno sviluppo sostenibile che non comprometta la transizione energetica globale.

items.body:

Legambiente

26 Agosto 2025

Comunicati stampa

Crisi climatica

Il ghiacciaio Solda arretra e diventa sempre più nero. Il bilancio di Carovana dei ghiacciai

26 Agosto 2025

Legambiente

26 Agosto 2025

Comunicati stampa

Crisi climatica

In Alto Adige i ghiacciai arretrano a ritmi preoccupanti e il paesaggio alpino cambia di continuo.

Il ghiacciaio Solda il più sofferente tra quelli del gruppo Ortles-Cevedale. Nel 2025 la sua fronte è arretrata di 26 metri rispetto al 2024 ridisegnando anche il paesaggio intorno: da un lato colate detritiche e i crolli, lembi di ghiacciaio morto, ma anche rock glacier, dall’altro il bosco e nuovi ecosistemi occupano gli spazi dove prima c’era il ghiaccio. 
 
“Importante monitorare, non solo i ghiacciai, ma anche l’evoluzione del paesaggio alpino per comprenderne gli eventuali rischi e adottare un modello di fruizione turistica meno consumistica, più sostenibile  e capace di conciliare sviluppo territoriale e bisogni delle comunità locali”.

Un ghiacciaio in arretramento, sempre più di colore nero, coperto in larga parte da un mare di detriti, un mix di roccia, fango e ghiacciaio. Intorno un paesaggio alpino che cambia in maniera rapida e veloce. Appare così il ghiacciaio Solda, del gruppo Ortles-Cevedale, in Alto Adige nel cuore del Parco Nazionale dello Stelvio, dove ha fatto tappa Carovana dei ghiacciai di Legambiente accompagnata dagli operatori del Servizio Glaciologico CAI Alto ADIGE. Nel 2025 la fronte del ghiacciaio, stando alle misurazioni appena fatte dagli operatori, è arretrata di 26 metri rispetto al 2024 confermando il trend medio decennale di 20 metri l’anno di ritiro. Un dato preoccupante in prospettiva storica se si pensa che nella seconda metà dell’800 il ghiacciaio arrivava poco a monte del parcheggio della funivia Solda, mentre oggi si concentra solo nella parte alta della montagna dove si alternano colate detritiche e lembi di ghiacciaio morto. Intorno, un paesaggio in continuo cambiamento: laghetti che si formano ad alta quota, un mare di detriti rocciosi che si estendono sopra e sotto la fronte del ghiacciaio, mentre bosco e nuovi ecosistemi si insediano dove prima c’era il ghiaccio.

I dati, presentati oggi in conferenza stampa a Bolzano presso la sede della Galleria Civica, sono frutto delle misurazioni effettuate lunedì in quota dagli operatori del Servizio Glaciologico CAI Alto Adige (SGAA), alle quali ha partecipato il team di Carovana dei ghiacciai, la campagna di Legambiente in collaborazione con CIPRA Italia e con la partnership scientifica della Fondazione Glaciologica Italiana. Durante la tappa sono stati anche osservati fenomeni geomorfologici connessi allo stato del ghiacciaio: in particolare preoccupa l’instabilità della morena laterale destra connessa alla fusione di nuclei di ghiaccio posti all’interno dei depositi glaciali e la crescita di coperture detritiche nel settore soprastante la fronte, per effetto di crolli e di colate, soprattutto dal fianco destro del ghiacciaio. In generale preoccupa anche lo stato di salute dei ghiacciai in Alto Adige. Dal 1997 al 2023, stando ai dati dell’ufficio Idrologia e dighe Provincia Autonoma di Bolzano, la superficie dei ghiacciai in Alto Adige si è quasi dimezzata passando da 122, 2 km2 a 72,2 km2. In diminuzione anche il numero dei ghiacciai: se nel 1997 erano 234, nel 2023 si è passati a 203, mentre nello stesso periodo aumentano le placche glaciali passate da 325 a 729 unità a causa della frammentazione dei ghiacciai.

I commenti
 “Sotto i nostri occhi – commenta Vanda Bonardo, responsabile nazionale Alpi di Legambiente e presidente di CIPRA ITALIA – il paesaggio glaciale alpino cambia: i ghiacciai arretrano, spariscono servizi ecosistemici e ne emergono di nuovi. È quello che abbiamo contrastato anche in Alto Adige nella terza tappa di Carovana dei ghiacciai. Questa trasformazione porta rischi crescenti, in quota e a valle, e impone una maggiore attenzione e un monitoraggio sia per comprendere meglio gli eventuali rischi sia per ripensare un modello di fruizione turistica della montagna. Il turismo del futuro dovrà fondarsi su un rapporto sostenibile tra uomo e natura, come ricorda ogni anno il dossier Nevediversa di Legambiente. Ripensare la gestione di questi spazi significa, però, anche mettere al centro le comunità locali, ascoltarne i bisogni e garantire una buona qualità della vita, sia per chi abita stabilmente la montagna sia per chi la frequenta. Solo in questo modo i beni comuni delle terre alte potranno avere un futuro: non come risorse da esaurire, ma come patrimonio condiviso”.
 
“Dal confronto fra le osservazioni fatte in questa tappa della Carovana e altri dati raccolti dagli operatori glaciologici SGAA – commentano Marco Giardino, vicepresidente della Fondazione Glaciologica Italiana e docente dell’Università di Torino, e Pietro Bruschi presidente del Servizio Glaciologico CAI Alto Adige – emerge che la deglaciazione in Alto Adige prosegue in modo diseguale nello spazio e nel tempo. Se per il ghiacciaio della Vedretta Lunga nella Val Martello viene segnalato quest’anno un arretramento record di circa 240 metri (G. Benetton, SGAA), per il ghiacciaio Solda la deglaciazione degli ultimi anni prosegue stabilmente intorno a 20 metri di media all’anno come ritiro frontale. Queste differenze sono però accompagnate da una trasformazione del paesaggio alpino simile e molto intensa: si registrano colate detritiche che si sovrappongono al ghiacciaio stesso, emergono lembi di ghiaccio morto dalle morene, rock glacier si destabilizzano e dai versanti montuosi il materiale detritico viene trasportato rapidamente verso valle. In ogni caso il segnale che riceviamo è quello di una accelerazione del cambiamento del paesaggio alpino”.

Il tema dell’arretramento dei ghiacciai in Alto Adige e il focus sul cambiamento del paesaggio alpino sono stati affrontati da Carovana dei Ghiacciai insieme ad esperti e a rappresentati del CAI Alto Adige anche nel convegno dal titolo “Clima e ghiacciai. Le variazioni del paesaggio glaciale in Alto Adige” organizzato ieri pomeriggio presso la sede del CAI Alto Adige, (Viale Europa 53). L’iniziativa ha avuto il patrocinio del CAI Alto Adige e del Servizio Glaciologico Alto Adige. Con l’occasione è stato anche presentato il libro “I ghiacciai dell’Alto Adige” (Secchieri F. Bruschi P. – ed. CIERRE).

Testimonial di tappa
A sostenere Carovana dei ghiacciai, anche quest’anno, diversi testimonial del mondo della musica, dello spettacolo, della scrittura, dello sport.  In questa tappa la videotestimonianza del trail runner Francesco Puppi e della poetessa Antonella Anedda. Il trailer runner, due volte vicecampione nella OCC targata UTMB, e trionfatore della Transgrancanaria Marathon, nel video racconta il suo legame con la montagna che rappresenta il terreno dove pratica il suo sport, ma anche l’ambiente dove si sente più a suo agio. Ha scelto di sostenere Carovana dei ghiacciai perché è un bel modo per creare consapevolezza sul tema crisi climatica e fusione dei ghiacciai. La poetessa Anedda, invece, nella sua videotestimonianza apre ricordando come difendere un ghiacciaio sia un gesto politico e al tempo stesso un gesto poetico. Sul canale youtube di Legambiente il video integrale.

Prossime tappe Carovana dei ghiacciai 2025
Dopo le prime tappe in Svizzera, Lombardia e Alto Adige, Carovana dei ghiacciai si sposterà in Germania dove arriverà per la prima volta per monitorare dal 26 al 29 agosto il ghiaccio Zugspitze. Poi tornerà in Italia, per l’ultima tappa in Piemonte, sui ghiacciai della Bessanese e della Ciamarella (dal 30 agosto al 2 settembre). Obiettivo della campagna è il monitoraggio dello stato di salute dei ghiacciai alpini, in Italia e anche oltre confine, portando in primo piano diversi temi: dagli effetti della crisi climatica in quota e a valle, agli eventi meteo estremi che stanno ridisegnando il profilo della montagna, dall’overtourism alla tutela della biodiversità, dalle politiche di adattamento ai cambiamenti climatici alle buone pratiche di sviluppo sostenibile.

In soccorso dei giganti bianchi
 Legambiente con Carovana dei ghiacciai 2025 invita tutti a firmare la petizione on line “Una firma per i ghiacciai” per chiedere al Governo azioni concrete partendo dall’attuazione di 7 interventi indicati nel Manifesto per una governance dei Ghiacciai e salvare il nostro ecosistema.
